text: [Music]
hi everyone
Anthony Fantino here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new RA the rugged man
album legends never die Ari the rugged
man is a New York rapper and this new LP
of his is essentially the guy's
celebrated return his last full-length
LP die rugged man died came out about
ten years ago at this point but the
dude's very long career but short
discography can be explained pretty
easily just by listening to his mouth
sure a lot of the lyrics the RA throws
out there are pretty nasty are pretty
vile but he also doesn't seem to
hesitate when it comes to pointing out
[ __ ] that he sees in the music
industry that I'm sure has gotten him in
more hot water than just some foul
language as far as the music industry
and the rap game goes he doesn't really
strike me as the kind of guy that likes
to play ball either and he's really kind
of bitter ever so slightly about how
he's gotten shafted in the music
industry and I can certainly understand
why in a recent interview with uncut Ari
revealed that early on in his career as
he was gaining buzz behind his music and
jive and Def Jam were basically scheming
on how to market him he was eventually
faced with their plan that they would
hide his white identity despite getting
the short end of the stick from his
record labels RA with is very real and
rebel and sort of no BS persona earned a
lot of connections musically with a lot
of different artists including wu-tang
as well as mob deep the notorious b.i.g
which is an endorsement he brags about
pretty heftily as well as Jedi Mind
Tricks and re still very much breathes
this era of hip-hop he's kind of a
traditionalist and still today on this
new record of his he's not really
interested in making nice nice industry
friends and connections he's the kind of
guy that if you're going to like him
it's going to be on his terms in the
first minute of
music or so that this album kicks off
with on the intro track RA lashes out at
hipster skinny jean wearing emo rappers
industry and mainstream puppets or just
in general people who aren't ready to
hear real hip-hop which is about Rhymes
and writing them down in notebooks even
takes a swing it internet nerds
personally I think it's pretty silly
that Ari would take a swing of people
who could become potential fans still
it's not like his disclaimer has no
accuracy whatsoever his music really is
for people who want to hear fast
impressive flows that want to hear
lyrics and dissect bars he's not the
most emotive or over-the-top rapper
you're ever going to hear his voice for
the most part on his tracks is pretty
flat and monotone with his low heavy ass
voice the lead single off of this LP the
People's Champ breaks through with a
huge freaking beat it is the anthem of
the album and it is loud it is proud the
beat on this thing is bombastic it's a
little cheesy but the dude has some
pretty funny lines comparing his flow to
the Sistine Chapel and this one line
about having identity issues and
self-hatred and calls himself a
pissed-off Wigga who just stepped off
the slave ship the dude is nasty
offensive politically incorrect in more
ways than one and he couldn't be farther
away from being apologetic about it the
next track on here a track that I also
liked which also has a sort of cheesy B
and a really cheesy cheesy hook so goo B
now I'm still won over by how
charismatic this dude is the song is
peppered with some references to older
hip-hop music that influenced Ari the
rugged man but mostly the track is a
look at his kind of weird personality
painting himself as this dirty guy who's
got stinky breath he's grimy as hell and
there's even this line in here where he
calls himself a white guy who's ruining
what black people invented there are a
lot of spots on this LP where Ari comes
off as a self-hating [ __ ] who I'm
sure many of you will love to hate as
well but there are spots on this thing
where man is this guy earnest and
heartfelt the song legends never die the
I'll track on this thing is a look at
his relationship with his father another
track on here where I'm not really 100%
on the beat it's this heavy-handed
rhythm with a little bit of acoustic
guitar sampled in the back just feels
too much like it's grabbing for sadness
but arias performance on this beat to me
makes it completely irrelevant the song
opens up with just our a being with his
father in his final moments in the
hospital his dad fighting cancer but
it's not really a depressing track
because it evolves into just him
reflecting on the amazing relationship
that he had with his father how he
reflects upon his dad is just so
beautiful and so sentimental it
seriously makes me feel like I wish I
could mean half as much to someone one
day and then he paints his dad as this
guy who was loving who was kind but also
sort of crazy a trickster a music fan a
Vietnam vet and someone who was really
proud of his son for for doing what he
wanted to do and sort of chasing his
musical dreams and at the end of the
track where literally Ari gets choked up
saying the final words of his last verse
it's really intense moment there are
some other highlights on this LP like
the dangerous three which features
brother Olly as well as master ace it's
one of the few tracks where I really
love the instrumental on the track
there's a really epic beat changeup in
the middle of each verse that each MC on
this track handles very nicely verse for
verse RS collaboration with Hobson
doesn't go over too bad and hearing him
Vinnie Paz and Sadat X a rapper who are
a cut one of his earliest earliest
singles with like back in the 90s was
like a blast from the past there are
spots on this album where RA is very
just abrasive personality doesn't
completely vibe with me either I feel
it's just too corny or he's just trying
too hard to say something silly or
offensive or just insensitive just to
kind of but there are other spots on
here where he comes off as foul-mouthed
but self-aware like on the song shot in
the head where he's going on and on and
on about how much of a disgusting person
he is so much so that he's making
liberals want to give him the death
penalty conservatives are wishing
he was aborted and right in the middle
of the song this weird voice comes in
and says hey why don't you rap about
something positive like politics or like
the environment or something I'm not
even going to spoil the verse for you
but the song gets even more hilarious
from there the only thing about the
track that I think is is really
absolutely crappy but I guess it really
sort of goes with the theme of the song
is the surprise opera vocal that covers
the hook on this track yes an opera
vocal which shows up more than once on
this album and in this particular
instance it's singing ah I'm a piece of
[ __ ] I'm a [ __ ] butt o re spits a
very apolitical verse on this track but
he goes further to make a song like
media midgets for example where to me it
really kind of feels like he's trying
too hard to be like [ __ ] the TV [ __ ] the
radio mm and I do agree generally with
the sentiment of the song it's just that
here and maybe a few other moments on
this album I feel like he's just trying
too hard to school me learn me something
and another track on here bang boogie
while it is a good track it really only
feels like half of a complete song and I
know I've already said that there are
some beats on this album that I don't
really care for but I could seriously
rail against some of the instrumentals
on this album corny classical music
samples all over them that take the most
obvious and endlessly sampled pieces of
music from these great compositions
songs like Tom Thumb laugh clown laugh
as well as underground hits and the song
hallelujah feels like some tech9 and
Chris calico afterbirth
seriously the hook and the beat on this
track is so gaudy even ICP would like
think twice about using it it's got to
be the worst course on the entire album
second worst silver medal goes to the
song love to [ __ ] which has a sung R and
B hook on it about putting it up that
but it does kind of make me giggle
though overall re the rugged man can be
a kind of dicey dude there are moments
when I'm completely repulsed by him and
other spots on here like the closing
track life is precious if you give this
track a listen one of the most
moving hip-hop songs you'll hear all
year ari is an acquired taste I do think
there are a lot of likable qualities
about him and I would like to say that
this comeback of his is maybe just the
start of a new beginning and something
greater to come in the future but I have
a sneaking suspicion that he's the kind
of artist who is sort of stuck in his
ways and just wants to do what he wants
to do without worrying about evolving or
doing something new or sort of doing
something revolutionary he's just going
to kind of do what's comfortable for him
and that's completely fine if it pleases
his fans I'm feeling a decent two strong
six on this album if you've given it a
listen what did you think of it did you
love it did you hate it why what do you
think I should review next and that's it
thanks for watching Anthony Fantan o RA
the rugged man forever
[Music]
you
